awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Allen R. Gehret is "Asymptotic Differential Algebra and Model Theory of Logarithmic Transseries and H-Fields." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California-Los Angeles, and the sponsoring scientist is Matthias Aschenbrenner.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
I completed the three-year NSF PostDoctoral Research Fellowship at UCLA from 2017-2020. During this period, I made concrete progress on my main research program "Model Theory of Logarithmic Transseries" and I began new research projects in the area of "distal structures".

A logarithmic transseries is a type of series which contains not only the variable ``x'', but also iterated logarithms ``log(x)'', ``log(log(x))'', etc (see accompanying image of a ``typical logarithmic transseries''). These objects arise naturally as formal asymptotic expansions of certain algebraic-differential equations whose solutions may be difficult to describe by more traditional means. Outside of logic, transseries have found use in high-energy physics, combinatorics, dynamical systems, and computer algebra, to name a few areas. The goal of the project ``Model Theory of Logarithmic Transseries'' is to understand the differential field of all logarithmic transseries. More specifically, I would like to find an appropriate language and collection of rules (i.e., axioms) which completely govern the solvability of such equations in this context. The benefit of ``unlocking'' the structure in this way is that it would enable deeper model theoretic analysis of asymptotic differential equations in this setting and it would anoint this structure as an appropriate ``universal domain'' for use by non-logicians interested in these types of equations. I began this project in 2012 as my PhD dissertation project. At that time, the research culminated in a promising strategy with partial results, and I was able to narrow the remaining hurdles down to three definite conjectures/obstructions. During the period of the NSF Fellowship, I was able to completely resolve one of the three conjectures, and gain valuable insight on the remaining two.

Separate from, but related to, the logarithmic transseries project, I made contributions to the study of ``distal structures''. A (model-theoretic) structure is distal essentially if every aspect of it is controlled by linear orders; either explicitly or in some hidden way. For instance, the fields of real numbers and p-adic numbers are distal, the complex numbers are not distal but have a distal expansion, whereas infinite fields of characteristic p can never have a distal expansion. With Elliot Kaplan, we showed that the asymptotic couple of the field of logarithmic transseries is distal. With Travis Nell, we produced a distal expansion for a certain non-distal expansion of the ordered group of real numbers, answering a question of Pierre Simon in the process. Finally, with Matthias Aschenbrenner, Artem Chernikov, and Martin Zeigler we investigated distality and distal expansions of valued fields and related structures. Each of these three projects resulted in publications, and the last of which has already contributed to the research of others.

Aside from these contributions to research, at UCLA I created and ran the Graduate Student Model Theory Seminar. This weekly seminar brought together graduate students, postdocs, and faculty in model theory and logic to study a variety of topics including o-minimality, pseudofinite fields, and dp-finite fields. This was also a venue for graduate students to practice preparing and giving talks.


Last Modified: 12/11/2022
Modified by: Allen R Gehret
